\documentclass[english]{article}
\usepackage[T1]{fontenc}
\usepackage[latin9]{luainputenc}
\usepackage{geometry}
\geometry{verbose,tmargin=0.75in,bmargin=0.5in,lmargin=0.4in,rmargin=0.4in}
\usepackage{amstext}
\usepackage{amssymb}
\usepackage{babel}
\begin{document}
\title{Math 320 HW 9}
\maketitle

\section*{1)}

For each of the following sets with the given binary operations, show
$R$ is a ring.

\subsection*{a)}

Let $R=\left\{ a+bi|a,b\in\mathbb{Z}\right\} =\mathbb{Z}\left[i\right]$
be the set of Gaussian integers (the complex numbers with integer
coefficients) under the usual definition of addition and multiplication
of complex numbers. 

\subsection*{b)}

Let $X$ be a set. Let $R=P\left(X\right)$ the power set of $X$.
Let $A+B=A\cup B-A\cap B$ (recall this is the symmetric difference)
and $AB=A\cap B$. 

\section*{2)}

For each of the rings in \textbf{1)}, determine

\subsection*{a)}

Is $R$ commutative?

\subsection*{b)}

Does $R$ have any zero divisors?

\subsection*{c)}

Does $R$ have a unity? If so, which elements of $R$ are units?

\subsection*{d)}

Is $R$ an integral domain?

\section*{3)}

Consider the ring of polynomials $R=\mathbb{Z}\left[x\right]$. 

\subsection*{a)}

Show $\left\langle x^{2}+1\right\rangle =\left\{ r\left(x^{2}+1\right)|r\in\mathbb{Z}\left[x\right]\right\} $
is an ideal of $R$. 

\subsection*{b)}

Show $\mathbb{Z}\left[x\right]\slash\left\langle x^{2}+1\right\rangle \approx\mathbb{Z}\left[i\right]$.
(Hint, the mapping $\phi\left(ax+b+\left\langle x^{2}+1\right\rangle \right)=ai+b$
is one possible isomorphism).

\subsection*{c)}

Show $\left\langle x^{2}+1\right\rangle $ is a prime ideal but not
a maximal ideal. (Hint: $\mathbb{Z}\left[x\right]$ is a commutative
ring with unity).

\section*{4)}

For $f\left(x\right),g\left(x\right)$ in polynomial ring $R$, find
$q\left(x\right),r\left(x\right)$ such that $f\left(x\right)=g\left(x\right)q\left(x\right)+r\left(x\right)$
and such that $\text{deg}\left(r\left(x\right)\right)<\text{deg}\left(g\left(x\right)\right)$

\subsection*{a)}

$g\left(x\right)=x^{2}+x$, $f\left(x\right)=x^{5}+4x^{2}+1$, $R=\mathbb{Z}_{5}\left[x\right]$

\subsection*{b)}

$g\left(x\right)=x+1$, $f\left(x\right)=x^{5}+x^{3}+x^{2}+1$, $R=\mathbb{Z}_{2}\left[x\right]$

\section*{5)}

Show $x^{2}+3$ is irreducible over $\mathbb{Z}_{5}$ but is reducible
over $\mathbb{Z}_{7}$.

\section*{6)}

Let $R$ be a ring and let $a,b\in R$. Show the difference of squares
formula $\left(a-b\right)\left(a+b\right)=a*a-b*b$ holds if and only
if $R$ is a commutative ring.

\section*{7)}

Let $r\in R$. Let $S_{r}=\left\{ x\in R|xr=0\right\} $. Show $S_{r}$
is a subring of $R$. 

\section*{8)}

Show that if $I_{1},I_{2}$ are ideals of $R$, then $I_{1}\cap I_{2}$
is an ideal of $R$.

\section*{9)}

If $R$ is a commutative ring, show $\text{Char}\left(R\left[x\right]\right)=\text{Char}\left(R\right)$.
\end{document}
